Suppose $2 \leq p < \infty \textrm{ and } f,g \in L^p$.\
$$\begin{aligned}
\left\| \frac{f+g}{2} \right\|_p^p + \left\| \frac{f-g}{2} \right\|_p^p
     & = &
\int \left| \frac{f+g}{2} \right|^p \,d\mu + \int \left| \frac{f-g}{2} \right|^p \,d\mu \\
     & = & 
\frac{1}{2^p} \left( \int \left| f+g \right|^p \, d\mu + \int \left| f-g \right|^p \,d\mu \right).\end{aligned}$$
By the triangle inequality, we have the following two inequalities
$$|f+g|^p\le |f|^p+|g|^p\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad |f-g|^p\le |f|^p+|g|^p,$$
and summing the two inequalities we get
$$|f+g|^p+|f-g|^p\le 2(|f|^p+|g|^p).$$ This means that expression (2)
above is less than or equal to $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2^{p-1}}\int (|f|^p + |g|^p) \,d\mu.\end{aligned}$$ Hence it
follows that $$\begin{aligned}
\left\| \frac{f+g}{2} \right\|_p^p + \left\| \frac{f-g}{2} \right\|_p^p
   & \le &
\frac{1}{2^{p-1}}\left(\int |f|^p \,d \mu + \int |g|^p \,d\mu \right) \\
   & = &
\frac{1}{2^{p-1}} \left( \left\| f \right\|_p^p + \left\| g \right\|_p^p \right),\end{aligned}$$
which since $p\ge 2$ directly implies the desired inequality.
